body:
> > I’m hesitant to include this for 0.12.1
> 
> I didn't want to go this into 0.12.1 as well :)
> 
> I'll try and take a look at those assumptions as well. Thanks for reviewing.

So now that I'm seeing that Spark 3.2 is already using this version of Parquet, I have a lot less concern in general. Though we do use our own read path, so the assumptions are probably still good to check.

Thanks for taking care of this @nastra!

@szehon-ho, I see that there could be multiple data files here, but I don't quite see how the current code would get it wrong. Still, being more careful and making sure the snapshot ID matches the actual data file is likely to fix it if that's the problem.

@rdblue I think import file sequence numbers will cause unnecessary complexity, and the sequence number of manifest list can mean file commit sequence, the data file sequence number just describe different sequence of snapshot and data file, but manifest list sequence numbers can do this too, because there is snapshotid in manifest list file ,so wo don't need hold same sequence numbers for one snapshot in the snapshot and manifest list. So even if we import file sequence numbers it just cause the same effect as the sequence number of manifest list.
Thanks @szehon-ho and @stevenzwu for the explaining and check.
@rdblue , any other concern for this PR ?
Thanks, @RussellSpitzer @rdblue @szehon-ho @kbendick!
cc @wypoon @pan3793 @kbendick @flyrain @karuppayya @szehon-ho @rdblue @RussellSpitzer
+1 for 1.12.2. Thank you, @nastra and @kbendick .
instead of row-level can can we perform copy on write if so how to do that with java

> Can we hold off on merging this until after 0.12.1 is released, pleased? That would make the process generally smoother.

Sure, @kbendick. What's the ETA of 0.12.1? I guess we are going to have a new branch like 0.12.x after 0.12.1, right? 
Looks like 0.12.x is there, https://github.com/apache/iceberg/tree/0.12.x. Do we release 0.12.1 based on master instead of 0.12.x?

@Reo-LEI  Could you take a look for the checkstyle issue ? 

```
Error: eckstyle] [ERROR] /home/runner/work/iceberg/iceberg/flink/src/main/java/org/apache/iceberg/flink/data/RowDataProjection.java:32:8: Unused import - org.apache.iceberg.StructLike. [UnusedImports]
```
I'd like to take a look for this PR today,  I think it's critical important feature for our flink users to read the v2 table. Thanks @Reo-LEI for picking up this PR !

> @Reo-LEI Could you take a look for the checkstyle issue ?
> 
> ```
> Error: eckstyle] [ERROR] /home/runner/work/iceberg/iceberg/flink/src/main/java/org/apache/iceberg/flink/data/RowDataProjection.java:32:8: Unused import - org.apache.iceberg.StructLike. [UnusedImports]
> ```

Sure, I will fix this latter.

For us (Nessie) it's rather an Iceberg thing, because the specialized procedures only work with the Nessie-Iceberg catalog. I think, that's the same for the existing procedures. (Not sure how to do it yet, but it would probably make sense to call those procedures from Flink as well.)

Using the https://github.com/EMCECS/ecs-object-client-java, the PR is redundant to create an abstraction for ECS APIs.

The following File IO PR is https://github.com/apache/iceberg/pull/3376.
And the parent PR of ECS Catalog with related discussion is https://github.com/apache/iceberg/pull/2807.

You can check these PRs for more details.

The test mock used a client-side mock that is easier for this repo. 
We decide to publish an ECS Mock in the future with more internal discussion and process.

I closed the first PR which create an abstraction of ECS APIs. Due to using our own SDK, this PR is redundant.

And the second PR is now available: https://github.com/apache/iceberg/pull/3376
I will resolve conflicts recently.

Hello @RussellSpitzer,

I have opened a draft PR for the same (https://github.com/apache/iceberg/pull/3375)
**It is working with default configurations.**

However I have some newbie questions as I am new to Iceberg. Please guide me.
a)  Do I have to copy the same code in spark/v3.2 folder as well ? currently I have it in v3.0 folder only.
b)  What is the best way to pass other arguments? I see that all the inputs has to go via TEXT form as we are using SQL for call procedure. Can I use below syntax ?

`filter = Expression (Should give as SQL string and convert expression internally?)
`
`strategy = "binpack" or "sort" 
`
`sort_order = comma separated column names [c1,c2,c3]`, what about asc/dsc, null_first/null_last ? 

`Options = comma separated "Key=value". `
Example, "min-input-files=5,min-file-size-bytes=1234,max-file-size-bytes=12345,target-file-size-bytes=1024,max-file-group-size-bytes=4096,rewrite-all=true"

c) I should handle all this with testcase in current PR or can split into multiple PRs ?

@rdblue suggested that we try and extract the version info from existing tags. 
I did some experimenting with the existing and other gradle git plugins. Most plugins were not exactly doing what we need or didn't really have a good way of being configured or were quite old and not maintained anymore, so I ended up using the existing git plugin that we already have (`com.palantir.git-version`). 

It supports searching for tag prefixes via `gitVersion(prefix: 'apache-iceberg-')` but that requires that our tags are annotated slightly different as the `prefix` must match a regex of the form `[/@]?([A-Za-z]+[/@-])+`, thus I adjusted the part where we annotate the tags from `Apache Iceberg x.y.z` to `apache-iceberg-x.y.z`. 

Also `gitVersion(prefix: 'apache-iceberg-')` just spits out a plain string and doesn't give any flexibility of extracing the MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH parts, thus I had to do some regex matching to extract what we need.

This PR seems close to me. I had only a few questions. I'll take a look at the benchmarks later today.

@RussellSpitzer @szehon-ho @rdblue @karuppayya @chenjunjiedada @pvary, could you take a look as well?

@nastra and I talked on Slack and created a `release-base-0.12.0` tag in master to mark where 0.12.0 was branched. That way we can keep the master version based on a tag, but it is obvious that it isn't a release tag.

@openinx, thanks for looking into it. Even if merge isn't the cause, having the wrong snapshot ID in the map could cause an issue so it's good to fix this and see if it helps. Thanks for working on this!
Looks good to me. Thanks @openinx!

@jun-he @nssalian does "expressions" feel a bit broad? What are your thoughts on breaking this down into smaller chunks? From what I can tell, I think implementing expressions relies on the following (roughly in this order):
- Literals
- Operations
- Terms
- Boolean Expressions 
- Predicates (bounded and unbounded)
- Binders
- Expression Visitors

Maybe each of this could be a separate issue + PR? The more incremental PRs would be easier to review as well.

I think this is a good first step, I always thought the menu of links was a little hidden on the old site. Do we have plans to put a better "What I should click on to start using right now" link or guide somewhere on this front page? I feel like this does have a similar problem to the current homepage, where I'm not sure where I should click to start.

Like I think getting started should be front and center somewhere :)

> I think this is a good first step, I always thought the menu of links was a little hidden on the old site. Do we have plans to put a better "What I should click on to start using right now" link or guide somewhere on this front page? I feel like this does have a similar problem to the current homepage, where I'm not sure where I should click to start.
> 
> Like I think getting started should be front and center somewhere :)

Totally agree! I started working on a new version of the welcome page but didn't want to hold up what was already becoming a large PR. I'm hoping to have a good set of beginner tutorials by next month and then a new welcome page could just have a super high level description of what Iceberg is along with a highlight of a few features and a "Learn More" or "Get Started" button that jumps right into some beginner tutorials.
can we do the same thing in java api without spark

Short answer: No
Long answer: You can do similar things with the pure java api but this would involve reading all the files you want to your local machine, combining them, then writing them from your local machine. I'm not sure if it would be easier to just manually implement that or to implement a "Local" RewriteDataAction

I believe this covered by one of the many schema change fixes @aokolnychyi did recently.

https://github.com/apache/iceberg/pull/2936
https://github.com/apache/iceberg/pull/2858

But could also be that the Spark Schema is out of sync and you need to call "REFRESH TABLE" since the cached version of the table metadata is out of sync. This is related to the Spark Caching catalog

Thanks for working on this refactoring! 

One major question I have is around the current versioning design. I see the entire `0.12.0` directory being created to store the `0.12.0` version of the doc. I wonder if we should do that, historically we have been doing this for javadoc which has led to a lot of code search issues in Intellij. I think a better way we can organize the doc is through the build and release process, so that in every release, checkout the historical release tags to copy the `site` to the correct version directory, and then release the website. But the source code always only contain 1 copy of the latest doc.

I also think the current refactoring also lacks a `latest` version, which displays the latest view of the docs. We should not map `/` to `/0.12.0`, but instead to `/latest` because we might have multiple releases of the website before the next new code version release.

From PR perspective, my opinion is that we can separate this to 2 PRs, 1 for style changes which I really like, another one for structural change that might potentially involve many files.

I hadn't considered including previous versions by copying in each branch, that's a great idea! The `mkdocs.yml` would have to include the full mapping of all branches but it should be straight-forward to parse the yaml and inject the `nav` section from each pervious version.

I'll try to carve out the structural/versioning changes and put it in a separate PR and keep this PR for just the style change.
@wang-x-xia do you plan to also create a new PR for the `EcsCatalog`, or keep updating this one? If you plan to create a new one, I will close this PR.
This looks good to me. To unblock the 0.12.1 release, we should get this in and fix the minor issue with the tests later.
The flink test failure isn't related `org.apache.iceberg.flink.TestFlinkTableSink > testHashDistributeMode`. I couldn't reproduce it locally.

Thanks for working on this! Almost forgot we haven't added the call procedure for this yet...

I remember Russell had laid out the arguments for the procedure in https://docs.google.com/document/d/1aXo1VzuXxSuqcTzMLSQdnivMVgtLExgDWUFMvWeXRxc, could you follow that proposal?

And I think #2719  is trying to tackle this same versioning issue but for javadoc. We can solve both of them in the same way. If we enable versioning for the entire website, then it does not make sense for each version of the website to have all the previous javadoc versions. We can have a 1:1 mapping between website and javadoc.

Btw, this also raises the question about how we deal with the python version releases. Maybe website release version should be different from the java release version, e.g. using release date as the website version number, and there is a table describing the java and python versions of the specific release date. But maybe that is too much for now?
Looks good to me. Thanks, @pvary! Sorry it took me a while to get to this review.

If a table column and a metadata column have the same name, the metadata column will never be requested. Currently we have very simple names for Iceberg metadata columns. I wonder if we should make it more complex on engine side, such as `_iceberg_partition` instead of just `_partition`. Any thoughts?
Yeah @kbendick I believe patch releases are done by applying needed PRs on top of the specific release branch. This can go into master without issue.
I converted Sam's list to a checklist in the description. We can keep track of steps there and mention this issue in each PR. Thanks, Sam!
Looks good. Thanks, @izchen!

So far `Catalog` has been a pluggable concept for cloud service integrations. It does not affect any Iceberg specific features, those are always controlled by the compute engine. Now we are saying that the `NessieCatalog` itself is more or less a compute engine that has its own list of unique features that other catalog cannot use. This is a big shift of the Iceberg catalog concept, and people can no longer easily switch across different implementations because of these catalog-specific procedures. it almost feel to me that Nessie should just implement another `NessieSparkCatalog` for Nessie users, and you can freely add all the extensions you'd like to have. Or we should try to push it as a Spark feature to easily register procedures from not a single but multiple sources.

I am also curious what approach you are taking for Delta Lake. They also have `io.delta.sql.DeltaSparkSessionExtension`, are you also adding a similar hook on their side?

@jackye1995 agreed we should combine this effort with the effort to version the javadoc. For the python versioning point, this point was also brought up by @jun-he and we decided to not worry about this for now since we don't have a number of python versions that need to be represented in versioned docs (yet).

I opened a separate [PR #3382](https://github.com/apache/iceberg/pull/3382) that just includes the styling changes. Once that's merged, I'll rebase this and use it for the structural changes. Thanks for the suggestion!
Can you also add unit and integration tests to verify the behavior?
Mostly looks good. Thanks for working on this!
Adding this to the Java 0.12.1 Release as https://github.com/apache/iceberg/pull/3258 is being included and otherwise this will break checkstyle.
@yyanyy @rdblue I updated to handle non-finite metrics from Orc files. Can you please take a look? Thanks!

I still do not get why you need to open a new transaction for each thread. The transaction is supposed to be opened at operation start time and only updated in batch after the data files or manifest files are aggregated. What is exactly the use case that would led to the use pattern you describe?
Can you rebase off of the master branch? `git rebase -i upstream/master`

It seems quite dangerous to retry on any `TException` and retry forever. My opinion is that we can set a configurable max retry, and only retry based on exception content. This can be implemented using Iceberg's `Tasks` util class.
@rdblue done.  Not sure if its exactly what you meant, but I fixed the tests asserting the old position in the new subfolders (2.4 and 3.2).
That's a valid concern, @jackye1995. At the same time, it is kind of nice to be able to use the exact names as they are documented in the spec. Maybe, we can add an alias and support both?
Closed via #3366

thanks for the review @rdblue @kbendick 
first time contributing to oss, still trying to navigate the setup and conventions 😅
Thanks, @rdblue @jackye1995 !
I use the refresh table command, but same error. And my table version is v1 format, use the latest release version iceberg-spark3-runtime-0.12.0.jar
I compile the jar with the branch master, try again, but the same error

> thanks for the review @rdblue @kbendick
> first time contributing to oss, still trying to navigate the setup and conventions 😅

Hey, there was a first time for all of us. And I definitely did not intuitively use git the way that is required in my projects with previous employers for proprietary software  (for very valid reasons given the unique ways people use the repository open source repository, including forks and ensuring the git commit history remains correct is imperative for people who cherry-pick PRs into their forks).

I was very fortunate to have people who took the time to show me the expected conventions etc. If you need any support at all (even with "silly" questions like the most appropriate way to ensure you rebase off of master without upsetting the git commit history) or anything else, please feel free to reach out to me on the Iceberg slack as well (you are on the [Iceberg slack](http://iceberg.apache.org/community/#slack) right?) 

Thanks again for your contribution @kevinliu-stripe!

@jackye1995 

No. The code of this PR won't update. I'll create a new PR for catalog implementation.
I think some discussion on this PR is active. So I didn't close it yesterday.
Close this PR is fine for me.

According to @jackye1995 's suggestion.
The `EcsFile` is separate to `EcsInputFile` and `EcsOutputFile`.
cc @samredai since this involves the website.
@jackye1995 : Thanks for sharing this doc. I will look into it and implement as per that.

for b),  @jackye1995 has pointed out that it is covered in the original design document (https://docs.google.com/document/d/1aXo1VzuXxSuqcTzMLSQdnivMVgtLExgDWUFMvWeXRxc).

So, I will go through it and implement accordingly.
Adding this to the 0.12.1 release as it makes cherry-picking cleaner.
@rdblue @szehon-ho @nastra updated based on the last discussion, could you take a look?

I will apply this PR to this branch as soon as it is merged (to keep the git history clean): https://github.com/apache/iceberg/pull/3386

There are a few patches in here that likely won't come in, but I needed to add them to show what issues were causing things to not be cleanly backported / cherry-picked.
@RussellSpitzer @rdblue @aokolnychyi @openinx

@kbendick thanks for reviewing. I pushed a comment with some documentation.

@aokolnychyi, Just wanted to get a better understanding with respect to row-level command support. In 3.2, are we scoping the changes within iceberg code base itself (PR you are planning this week) and then from 3.3 onwards the changes would go inside the spark code base which would be on the lines of the [SPIP](https://docs.google.com/document/d/12Ywmc47j3l2WF4anG5vL4qlrhT2OKigb7_EbIKhxg60/edit) and the [draft PR](https://github.com/apache/spark/pull/33008). I might be missing information here and wanted to better understand the approach.
Thanks for the review @jackye1995 !
I will take a look if no one picked up.

Thank you @samredai for this effort! Some humble comments from my side:
- Perhaps we can increase the size of the top banner, I find it pretty small.
- Perhaps we can increase the font of the left banner, they are as well small on my 27inch screen.
- How about adding a 'Slack' icon next to Github icon with iceberg account URL? With that this will be obvious for the users.
- I would say, if we move the 'Blogs' button to the left next to the github icon would make more sense.

Sorry there is an extra parenthesis here. Thanks, @kbendick
I adressed some comment and leave some comment to discuss. I think you can take another looks of this PR. @rdblue  @openinx @stevenzwu @kbendick 😄

@jackye1995 , @RussellSpitzer : 
I have added some more arguments. Also updated the document. 
As per me only `sort related options` and `where` arguments are pending. For `where` , I am not sure how to convert text to expression yet. For `sort related options` I am not sure whether to have as map or individual options. 
If ok, I want to handle this in subsequent PR. please review the current changes.

Also I should copy the same code in spark/v3.2 folder as well ?

p.s: Also let me know if any other arguments is missed.

> @jackye1995 , @RussellSpitzer : I have added some more arguments. Also updated the document. As per me only `sort related options` and `where` arguments are pending. For `where` , I am not sure how to convert text to expression yet. For `sort related options` I am not sure whether to have as map or individual options. If ok, I want to handle this in subsequent PR. please review the current changes.
> 
> Also I should copy the same code in spark/v3.2 folder as well ?
> 
> p.s: Also let me know if any other arguments is missed.

For "where" can you check and see if you can produce expressions using the Spark session's parser? I think you may be able to convert to expressions using the parser and then translate them using our Spark3 utils ... I'm not sure though.
Updating to the future! Thanks @nastra

@jackye1995 I don't think so. The mkdocs theme is an open source one called [windmill](https://github.com/gristlabs/mkdocs-windmill/tree/master/mkdocs_windmill/css) and it comes with fontawesome 4.7 which on it's [license page](https://fontawesome.com/v4.7/license/) says:

> Font Awesome is fully open source and is GPL friendly. You can use it for commercial projects, open source projects, or really just about whatever you want.

The theme itself includes an attribution to itself:

> Documentation built with MkDocs using Windmill theme by Grist Labs.

but I think it would be nice to include an attribution to fontawesome, although it's not required. What do you think about adding that to the footer?
Thanks, @nastra!
Thanks, @szehon-ho!
If you remove this, then the version in Javadoc will be the project version. Is that something that we want to change? I guess we don't build Javadoc from branches much.

@rdblue I couldn't find any place that would depend on `project.rootProject.version` being set to the branch name. There are a few places further below that use the branch name and those all seem to do the correct thing, so I'm assuming that `project.rootProject.version = getJavadocVersion()` isn't needed, but wanted to verify with you

Made the font bigger for the nav items and added a slack icon hyperlinked to the invitation to the iceberg slack. Also moved "Blogs" to be next to the slack icon. Suggested by @omarsmak in the [other pr](https://github.com/apache/iceberg/pull/3378#issuecomment-952741381) .
Thanks for the suggestions @omarsmak ! I've added them to [PR #3382](https://github.com/apache/iceberg/pull/3382#issuecomment-953194850) and it looks great (included a screenshot there).
cc @openinx

> Sorry there is an extra parenthesis here. Thanks, @kbendick

No worries @izchen! I don't think on the present CI it causes any issue.

It's just when I cherry-pick it to a branch that has the checkstyle set up before the recent CI refactor that it causes me this issue. So it's not really something you should have noticed as the test suite didn't complain. 👍
Thanks for adding this @samredai. I've been doing black formatting locally. :)
cc @jackye1995 @wypoon @pan3793 @kbendick @flyrain @rdblue @RussellSpitzer @karuppayya @szehon-ho
@jackye1995 @rdblue @RussellSpitzer, any thoughts on supporting both real and aliased metadata names?

@marton-bod, what is the use case for this type of writers? The spec requires the position delete records to be sorted by `file_path` and `pos`. If we are sorting the records anyway, why not include the `spec_id` and `partition` metadata columns as well? Is it because we don't support these metadata columns in some query engines?
This looks mostly good to me. We need to fix ORC writers and enable appropriate tests. I'd like to also know a little bit more about the use case.
